description: From echo +‎ -lalia; Latin ēchō from Ancient Greek ἠχώ (ēkhṓ, “reflected sound, echo”), and -lalia from Ancient Greek λαλιά (laliá, “talk, chat”).

entries.meaning: (clinical psychology) The immediate, involuntary, and repetitive echoing of words or phrases spoken by another.
An infant's repetitive imitation of vocal sounds spoken by another person, occurring naturally during childhood development.
Any apparently meaningless, repetitious noises, especially voices.
examples: There was the boom of a bass drum, and the voice of the orchestra leader rang out suddenly above the echolalia of the garden.
